choices.text: Behavioral analysis
Postmortem psychological profiling
Psychological autopsy
Retrospective mental health evaluation

questions.text: In a medicolegal case involving a sudden, unexplained death, a forensic psychiatrist is asked to conduct a specialized evaluation. The deceased individual had a history of mental health issues and the circumstances surrounding their death are unclear. The purpose of this evaluation is to determine the mental state of the deceased person before their death. What is this type of forensic psychiatric evaluation known as?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Psychological autopsy

 

Option C:

 

A psychological autopsy is an assessment conducted to determine the mental state of a deceased person prior to their death. This type of evaluation is often used in cases of sudden, unexplained, or suspected suicide deaths to understand the individual's psychological condition and factors that may have contributed to the death. It involves reviewing the individual's medical records, interviewing friends and family, and examining any available documents or communications from the deceased.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Behavioral analysis: This involves studying an individual's behavior patterns, typically to understand criminal behavior, personality disorders, or other psychological conditions. It is more focused on observable behaviors rather than assessing a deceased person's mental state before death.

 

Option B. Postmortem psychological profiling: Generally, refers to constructing a psychological profile of a living individual, often a criminal suspect, based on behavior and other evidence.

 

Option D. Retrospective mental health evaluation: This term could be considered a broad description of assessing someone's mental health state after an event or, in this case, after death. However, it is not as specific as 'psychological autopsy,' which is the established term for posthumously assessing a person’s mental state to understand the circumstances leading to their death, especially in cases of suspected suicide.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Psychological autopsy is an investigative procedure of reconstructing a person’s state of mind prior to death. This is based upon information gathered from personal documents, police and medical records and interviews with survivors of the deceased-families, friends and others who had contact with the person.

 

Ref: Reddy 33/e. Pg 120

choices.text: Mild
Moderate
Severe
Profound

questions.text: In a forensic evaluation involving a determination of competency, a 16-year-old individual is assessed for cognitive abilities. The individual's IQ test results indicate an IQ score of 40. In the context of this assessment, what is the level of mental retardation indicated by an IQ score of 40?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Moderate

 

Option B:

 

An IQ score of 40 falls within the range of moderate mental retardation. This level of intellectual disability is typically characterized by a significant impairment in cognitive functioning and adaptive behaviors. Individuals with moderate mental retardation may require support for daily living activities and may have limitations in academic skills.

 

Moderate - 35-50 IQ - 10% of all cases, can learn to speak, drop out of school after 2nd grade, can be trained to perform semi-skilled or unskilled work under supervision.

 

Intelligence Quotient (I.Q): (Binet-Simon test). It is the intellectual capacity of a person in relation to his chronological age, which is expressed as a percentage. Normal adult I.Q. is 90 - 110.

 

Mental Subnormality (oligophrenia): Amentia is retarded, incomplete or abnormal mental development. The term amentia has been replaced by mental retardation. Mental retardation refers to below average general intellectual functioning with typical onset in infancy or birth that must occur before 18 years of age. It includes mental sub normality and mental handicap. It signifies a condition of retarded, incomplete or abnormal mental development. I.Q. is below 70.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Mild: IQ score 50-70. Commonest type, 85-90% of all cases, can achieve vocational and social self-sufficiency with little support.

 

Option C. Severe: IQ score 20-35 - Recognized early in life with poor motor development (delayed milestones) and absent speech. Later in life, elementary training in personal health care can be given and taught to talk.

 

Option D. Profound: IQ score below 20 - 1-2% of cases, developmental milestones markedly delayed, associated physical disorders are present, and often need nursing care or life-support.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The educational objective is to understand the classification of intellectual disability based on IQ scores and to recognize that an IQ score of 40 is indicative of profound intellectual disability, which has significant implications for an individual's competency in legal contexts.

 

Ref: Reddy 33/e. Pg 484

choices.text: Ability to make a valid will
Criminal liability
Right to vote
Ability to give evidence

questions.text: During a legal consultation, a forensic psychiatrist is asked to assess the mental capacity of an elderly individual in the context of a disputed will. The individual, now deceased, had made significant changes to their will shortly before passing away. In this medicolegal context, what does testamentary capacity refer to?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Ability to make a valid will

 

Option A:

 

Testamentary capacity refers to the legal and mental ability of an individual to make or alter a valid will. This includes the ability to understand the nature and extent of their property, the natural beneficiaries of their estate, the legal effect of signing a will, and the ability to make decisions about the distribution of their property in a rational manner. In this case, assessing the testamentary capacity of the deceased individual is crucial to determine if the changes to the will were made with full understanding and intention. (Sec 31 IPC)

 

The requirements for a valid will –

 

  • A written and properly signed and witnessed document must exist.
  • The testator must be major, and of sound disposing mind, at the time of making the will.
  • Force, undue influence, or dishonest representation of facts, should not have been applied by others.
  • A sound disposing mind is a mind which has capacity of recollecting, judging and feeling the relations, connections and obligations of his family and blood relations.
  • Holograph will be one which is written by a testator in his own handwriting.
  • Persons can make valid wills during lucid interval.
  • A will is considered valid even though the testator committed suicide shortly after making a will, if there is no other evidence of mental disorder

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Criminal liability: This pertains to the ability to be held legally responsible for criminal actions, not related to making a will.

 

Option C. Right to vote: This is a civil right and does not specifically relate to the ability to make a will.

 

Option D. Ability to give evidence: While important, this refers to the capability to provide reliable and coherent testimony in legal proceedings, not testamentary capacity.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Testamentary capacity refers to the legal and mental ability of an individual to make or alter a valid will. This includes understanding the nature and extent of their possessions, the act of making a will, the claims to which they ought to give effect, and being free of any delusion that influences the disposition of their property.

 

Ref: Reddy 33/e. Pg 492 – 493

choices.text: Hasse’s rule
McNaughten’s rule
Durham’s rule
Curren’s rule

questions.text: In a high-profile criminal case, a forensic expert is called to testify regarding the mental state of the accused at the time of the crime. The defense argues that the accused, who has a documented history of mental illness, was not aware of the nature and quality of the act due to their mental condition. The prosecution, however, challenges this claim. The forensic expert is asked to clarify the applicable legal rules that govern the criminal responsibility of individuals deemed mentally ill at the time of committing a crime. Which of the following is NOT a recognized legal rule in this context for determining the criminal responsibility of the accused?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Hasse’s rule

 

Option A:

 

Hasse’s rule is a rough method of calculating the age of fetus. The other options listed are recognized in various jurisdictions and pertain to the insanity defense.

 

Procedure of examination of a mentally ill person is under Section 328 & 329 CrPC

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. McNaughten’s rule: This widely recognized rule asserts that an accused is not criminally responsible if, at the time of the act, they were suffering from a mental disease or defect that prevented them from knowing the nature and quality of the act or from understanding that it was wrong.

 

Option C. Durham’s rule: Also known as the "product test," it holds that an accused is not criminally responsible if the act was a product of mental disease or mental defect.

 

Option D. Curren’s rule: While not as widely known as McNaughten's or Durham's rules, it pertains to forensic psychiatry and legal assessments of insanity.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Assess the criminal responsibility of insane persons –

 

 

Ref: Reddy 33/e. Pg 494

choices.text: Admission only upon family request
Admission based on severe mental illness and inability to make decisions
Voluntary admission based on self-assessment of mental illness and capacity to make decisions
Mandatory admission for all diagnosed mental illnesses

questions.text: A forensic expert is discussing the Mental Health Act of 2017 with postgraduate medical students, focusing on the criteria for admission to mental health establishments. The expert explains the concept of "independent patient" and the conditions under which a person can be admitted. Which of the following best describes the admission criteria for independent patients under the Mental Health Act of 2017?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Voluntary admission based on self-assessment of mental illness and capacity to make decisions

 

Option C:

 

The Mental Health Act of 2017 allows for the admission of an "independent patient," which refers to someone who voluntarily requests admission for treatment of a mental illness and has the capacity to make healthcare decisions or requires minimal support in making decisions.

 

The Mental Health Act of 2017 in India outlines specific procedures and criteria for the admission, treatment, and discharge of individuals with mental illnesses. Key provisions include:

 

  1. Independent Admission: Adults who consider themselves to have a mental illness and wish to be admitted for treatment can do so as independent patients if they have the capacity to make their own healthcare decisions or require minimal support.
    1. Admission Criteria includes the severity of the mental illness, the likelihood of benefit from treatment, and an understanding of the admission's nature and purpose.
    2. Treatment: Patients must consent to treatment.
    3. Discharge: Patient can discharge themselves, without the consent of medical officers or mental health professionals, subject to certain conditions.
  2. Admission of Minors: Procedure includes the assessment by 2 psychiatrists or a combination of psychiatrists and mental health professionals. Factors include the severity of mental illness, the best interests of the minor, the need for admission, and the suitability of community-based alternatives.
    • Accommodation and Treatment: Accommodated separately from adults and given treatment with the informed consent of their nominated representative.
    • The admission and continued stay of minors are subject to periodic review and reporting to the concerned Board.

 

These provisions reflect a comprehensive approach to mental healthcare, prioritizing the rights and well-being of individuals with mental illnesses, while ensuring proper oversight and ethical standards in treatment and care.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Admission only upon family request: This is not a criterion for independent admission.

 

Option B. Admission based on severe mental illness and inability to make decisions: This refers to supported admission, not independent admission.

 

Option D. Mandatory admission for all diagnosed mental illnesses: The Act does not mandate admission for all diagnosed mental illnesses.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Mental Health Act of 2017 allows for the admission of independent patients under the principle that individuals who self-assess as having a mental illness and who retain the capacity to make healthcare decisions can voluntarily seek admission to a mental health establishment. This provision respects the autonomy of the individual and supports their right to access healthcare.

 

Ref: - Mental Health Act, 2017, MoHFW, India

choices.text: Cerebral edema
Concussive syndrome
Lucid interval
Post-traumatic amnesia

questions.text: A 35-year-old man, involved in a motorbike accident, was initially unconscious but regained consciousness and seemed coherent upon arrival at the emergency department. After a few hours, he experiences a rapid decline in consciousness and develops a headache and right-sided weakness. A CT scan of the head shows extradural hematoma. What is this clinical presentation, characterized by a period of initial recovery followed by a rapid deterioration in consciousness, classically known as?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Lucid interval

 

Option C:

 

Lucid Interval

 

  • It is a period in insanity during which all the signs and symptoms of insanity disappear, and behavior is like that of a normal person.
  • Lucid interval is common in mania and melancholia.
  • The person is responsible for all his acts performed during the period of lucid interval.
  • If he commits a crime, then he may take the plea of previous insanity. Moreover, it is difficult to know whether he was suffering from some mental illness at the time of committing the crime.
  • Lucid interval is also seen in head injuries (e.g. extradural hemorrhage)

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Cerebral edema - develops gradually, not characterized by a lucid interval.

 

Option B. Concussive syndrome - involves symptoms like headache and dizziness but does not include a rapid decline in consciousness.

 

Option D. Post-traumatic amnesia - involves memory loss but lacks the distinctive rapid deterioration after a lucid period.

 

Educational Objective:

 

"Lucid interval," a period of apparent recovery followed by a rapid deterioration in consciousness, is classically associated with extradural hematoma. This condition often results from arterial bleeding, typically from the middle meningeal artery, and is commonly seen following a head injury. The initial loss of consciousness is due to concussion, and the brief recovery period (lucid interval) is followed by a decline due to the accumulation of blood between the dura mater and the skull.

 

Ref:  Reddy 33/e. Pg 482

choices.text: Hemorrhage around eyes
Mastoid ecchymosis
Umbilical ecchymosis
Vaginal ecchymosis

questions.text: During a postmortem examination, a forensic expert observes ecchymosis over the mastoid region of a 30-year-old man who was a victim of a suspected assault. The decedent had no significant medical history, but the history of events suggests a fall with head trauma. This finding on the postmortem is significant and suggests a specific type of injury. What is this postmortem finding, indicative of basilar skull fracture, classically known as?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Mastoid ecchymosis

 

Explanation:

 

Battle's sign, or mastoid ecchymosis, is a classic postmortem finding indicating a basilar skull fracture. It manifests as bruising over the mastoid process behind the ear and typically becomes evident several hours or days post-injury. This sign, especially suggests a fracture in the skull base, often in the temporal bone region.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Hemorrhage around eyes - Known as 'raccoon eyes,' a sign of basilar skull fracture, but not Battle's sign.

 

Option C. Umbilical ecchymosis - Termed Cullen's sign, typically associated with acute pancreatitis, not related to head trauma.


Option D. Vaginal ecchymosis - Not related to head trauma; often seen in cases of trauma or abuse involving the genital area.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Battle’s sign: Bruising behind the ear appearing 36hr after head injury; may be confused with retro-auricular scalp bruise.

 

Ref: Reddy 33/e. Pg 185

choices.text: Valid, as the man was not under any legal guardianship.
Invalid, due to the man's mental state during the contract signing.
Valid, if it occurred during a lucid interval.
Invalid, unless ratified during a period of mental stability.

questions.text: A 65-year-old man with a history of bipolar disorder is undergoing a manic episode. His family discovers that he has sold a significant portion of his property during this phase. The family consults a legal advisor regarding the validity of the property sale. According to legal standards, which of the following best describes the validity of this contract?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Invalid, due to the man's mental state during the contract signing.

 

Option B:

 

Civil responsibility in the context of mental illness involves several key areas:

 

  • Property Management: Courts may appoint guardians for mentally ill individuals and order the sale of their property for debt payment, with only competent persons authorized to transfer property.
  • Contracts and Consent: Contracts made by mentally ill individuals are invalid if they lack understanding or rational judgment, except during lucid intervals. Consent given by an insane or intoxicated person is invalid if they cannot understand its nature and consequences.
  • Marriage, Divorce, and Adoption: Marriages can be nullified if one party is mentally unfit at the ceremony, and divorce laws vary by religion. Adoption is prohibited if either parent is mentally ill.
  • Testamentary Capacity: A valid will requires the testator to be of sound mind, understanding its nature and their property, and it must be signed in the presence of two witnesses. Wills are valid during lucid intervals but invalid if made under mental impairment or undue influence.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Valid, as the man was not under any legal guardianship - Legal guardianship status does not solely determine the validity of a contract. The mental state of the individual at the time of the contract is crucial.

 

Option C. Valid, if it occurred during a lucid interval - Although contracts made during lucid intervals are valid, the question scenario describes a manic episode, not a lucid interval.

 

Option D. Invalid, unless ratified during a period of mental stability - While ratification during mental stability can be a factor, the primary issue here is the man's mental state at the time of contract formation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A contract is considered invalid if one of the parties, at the time of making it, was incapable of understanding it and forming a rational judgment as to its effect upon his interests due to mental illness. In this case, the man's manic episode likely impaired his capacity to understand the contract.

 

Ref:  Reddy 33/e. Pg 491

choices.text: The will is valid as it was handwritten and witnessed.
The will is invalid if the testator was under undue influence.
The will is invalid as it was not certified by a legal authority.
The will is valid only if made during a lucid interval of mental illness.

questions.text: A forensic expert is reviewing a case involving the will of a deceased individual. The will was handwritten by the testator, a 55-year-old man who had been diagnosed with a progressive neurological disorder. It was written and signed in the presence of two witnesses a few weeks before the man's passing. The forensic expert is assessing the validity of the will based on legal standards. Considering the information provided, which of the following is most likely to affect the validity of this holograph will?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) The will is invalid if the testator was under undue influence.

 

Option B:

 

A holograph will, written by the testator in their own handwriting, is valid if the testator is a major, understands the nature of the will, has knowledge of the property to be disposed of, and can recognize those with justifiable claims on their property. Additionally, the will must be executed voluntarily without any undue influence from any person. The presence of two witnesses further validates the will. The potential influence on the testator, especially given his neurological condition, is a key factor in determining the will's validity.

 

Will is valid under special circumstances:

 

  1. Made by deaf, dumb or blind persons.
  2. Made during lucid intervals of mental illness.
  3. Suicide by testator immediately after making the will, in the absence of any mental illness.

 

Will is invalid when made by imbecile or drunk persons or under insane delusions, because the testator was incapable of rational views and judgment.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. The will is valid as it was handwritten and witnessed - While being handwritten and witnessed are important factors, they alone do not guarantee the validity of the will. The mental state of the testator and the presence of undue influence are also critical considerations.

 

Option C. The will is invalid as it was not certified by a legal authority - Certification by a legal authority is not a requirement for the validity of a holograph will. The key factors are the testator's mental capacity, voluntariness, and the presence of witnesses.

 

Option D. The will is valid only if made during a lucid interval of mental illness - While wills made during lucid intervals of mental illness can be valid, the scenario provided does not specify that the testator was suffering from a mental illness. The question of lucid intervals typically arises in cases of intermittent mental illnesses, not progressive neurological disorders.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Testamentary Capacity: A valid will requires the testator to be of sound mind, understanding its nature and their property, and it must be signed in the presence of two witnesses. Wills are valid during lucid intervals but invalid if made under mental impairment or undue influence.

 

Holograph will: Will written by the testator in his own handwriting.

 

Ref: Reddy 33/e. Pg 492-493

choices.text: He is criminally responsible because he was aware of his actions.
He is not criminally responsible due to his inability to understand the nature of the act.
He is criminally responsible because he acted under voluntary intoxication.
He is criminally responsible as he could not control his impulse due to mental illness.

questions.text: A 40-year-old man is on trial for the murder of his neighbor. During the trial, it is revealed that he suffers from schizophrenia and was experiencing delusions at the time of the crime. He believed his neighbor was a threatening wild animal. According to the Legal Test of Insanity, how is this individual's criminal responsibility likely to be assessed?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) He is not criminally responsible due to his inability to understand the nature of the act.

 

Option B:

 

The Legal test of Insanity (The ‘Right or Wrong’ test) - Under this test, a person was not criminally responsible, if at the time of the crime, he did not know the nature of the act or that it was wrong. It excludes responsibility of the insane for the commission of crime, and has the following requirements:

 

  1. There should be evidence of mental disease.
  2. This mental disease or defect must exist at the time of commission of crime.
  3. It should be of such degree that the person is unable to understand that the act is wrong and/or contrary to the law.

 

Criminal Responsibility - Sec. 84 IPC deals with the criminal responsibility of insane persons.

It states that “Nothing is an offence which is done by a person who, at the time of doing it, by reason of unsoundness of mind, is incapable of knowing the nature of the act, or what he is doing is either wrong or contrary to the law”.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. He is criminally responsible because he was aware of his actions - This option does not consider the impact of his mental illness and delusions on his understanding of the act.

 

Option C. He is criminally responsible because he acted under voluntary intoxication - There is no indication in the scenario that the man was intoxicated; his actions were influenced by his mental illness.

 

Option D. He is criminally responsible as he could not control his impulse due to mental illness - While impulse control is a factor in some legal considerations of insanity, the 'Right or Wrong' test focuses primarily on the individual's understanding of the nature and wrongfulness of their act.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Under the Legal Test of Insanity ('Right or Wrong' test), an individual is not criminally responsible if, at the time of the crime, they did not know the nature of the act or that it was wrong, due to a mental disease or defect. In this case, the man's delusion that his neighbor was a wild animal suggests that he was unable to understand the true nature of his act, fulfilling the criteria for this legal test.

 

Ref: Reddy 33/e. Pg 493-494

choices.text: A person who commits a crime during a lucid interval of mental illness can be held criminally responsible.
A person is not criminally responsible if they were unable to understand the nature of the act due to a mental disease.
Intoxication or drunkenness can be used as an excuse against criminal responsibility.
A person under an insane delusion is judged as though the delusional facts were real.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is NOT true according to the McNaughten Rule regarding the determination of criminal responsibility?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Intoxication or drunkenness can be used as an excuse against criminal responsibility.

 

Option C:

 

According to the McNaughten Rule, a person is not criminally responsible if they cannot understand the nature of their act or that it is wrong due to a mental disease or defect. However, this rule does not consider voluntary intoxication or drunkenness as valid excuses for criminal responsibility. The rule focuses on the cognitive ability to distinguish between right and wrong at the time of the crime.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. A person who commits a crime during a lucid interval of mental illness can be held criminally responsible - This is true as the McNaughten Rule considers the mental state at the time of the crime; if the person was lucid, they are responsible.

 

Option B. A person is not criminally responsible if they were unable to understand the nature of the act due to a mental disease - This aligns with the McNaughten Rule, which stipulates that a lack of understanding of the act due to mental illness negates criminal responsibility.

 

Option D. A person under an insane delusion is judged as though the delusional facts were real - This is accurate according to the McNaughten Rule, where the reality perceived by a mentally ill individual is taken into account in determining criminal responsibility.

 

Educational Objective:

 

McNaughten Rule's (the right or wrong test; the legal test) - ‘Every man is to be presumed to be sane, and to possess a sufficient degree of reason to be responsible for his crimes, until the contrary be proved; and that to establish a defense on the ground of insanity, it must be clearly proved that at the time of committing the act, the party accused was laboring under such a defect of reason from disease of the mind, so as not to know the nature and quality of the act he was doing, or if he did know it, that he did not know that what he was doing was wrong’.

 

Ref: - Reddy 33/e. Pg 493

choices.text: Forensic psychiatrists are responsible for diagnosing and treating all types of mental illness.
Forensic psychiatrists often provide expert testimony in legal cases involving mental health issues.
Forensic psychiatrists evaluate the competency of individuals to stand trial.
Forensic psychiatrists may assess the risk of reoffending in criminal cases.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is NOT true regarding the role of forensic psychiatrists?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Forensic psychiatrists are responsible for diagnosing and treating all types of mental illness.

 

Option A:


Role of Forensic psychiatrists –

 

  • They are called upon to produce legally binding documents, which are presented before the courts that can determine the course of an individual’s life and liberty, and his/her life choices.
  • An individual with a mental disorder should be assumed to have mental capacity to decide on various matters unless the contrary can be shown. The criterion for incapacity is based upon the following when it is proved that the person is -
  1. Unable to comprehend and retain information relevant to the decision and its consequences
  2. Incapable of believing the information
  3. Incapable of weighing up information to reach a decision.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Forensic psychiatrists often provide expert testimony in legal cases involving mental health issues - This is true. Forensic psychiatrists play a crucial role in legal cases by offering expert opinions on mental health issues relevant to the case.

 

Option C. Forensic psychiatrists evaluate the competency of individuals to stand trial - This is accurate. One of the key roles of forensic psychiatrists is to assess whether an individual is mentally competent to participate in legal proceedings.

 

Option D. Forensic psychiatrists may assess the risk of reoffending in criminal cases - This statement is correct. Part of the forensic psychiatrist's role can involve evaluating an individual's risk of reoffending, which is essential in criminal justice settings.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Forensic psychiatrists specialize in the interface between law and mental health. Their role includes providing expert testimony, evaluating competency to stand trial, and assessing the risk of reoffending. However, they are not solely responsible for diagnosing and treating all types of mental illness. This responsibility falls within the broader field of psychiatry, including various subspecialties that address different aspects of mental health.

 

Ref:  Reddy 33/e. Pg 480

choices.text: True insanity
Feigned insanity
A manic episode
Major depressive disorder

questions.text: A forensic psychiatrist is evaluating a 30-year-old man for the assessment of his mental state in relation to a criminal offense. During multiple interviews, the psychiatrist notes that the man's presentation of symptoms is variable and exaggerated, mainly when he is aware of being observed. He also appears to overact to show abnormalities in mood and resents repeated examinations. These observations are most consistent with which of the following?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Feigned insanity

 

Option B:

 

The features described in the scenario are indicative of feigned insanity. Key characteristics of feigned insanity include symptoms that are not directed to any particular type of insanity, exaggerated and variable activity only when the person is conscious of being observed, frequent changes in facial expressions, and resentment towards repeated examinations. These contrast with the features of true insanity, which typically include more consistent and uniform symptoms, irrespective of observation.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. True insanity - Characterized by gradual onset, uniform signs and symptoms specific to a type of insanity, and behaviors that are consistent whether or not the patient is being observed.

 

Option C. A manic episode - Involves periods of elevated mood, increased activity, and other symptoms, but does not typically include resenting examinations or variable symptoms based on observation.

 

Option D. Major depressive disorder - Characterized by a persistent low mood, lack of interest in activities, and other symptoms, but does not align with the overacting and variable presentation seen in feigned insanity.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Comparing the features of true insanity and feigned insanity:

 

True insanity typically has a gradual onset, often with a motive absent and predisposing factors like family history present. Symptoms are uniform and persistent across situations, with careless activity and mood fluctuations that match the individual's condition. In contrast, feigned insanity has a sudden onset, usually with a motive such as evading crime responsibility, lacks predisposing factors, and displays exaggerated and inconsistent symptoms that are often performed when observed. Additionally, those feigning insanity may resent repeated examinations due to the fear of being exposed.

 

Ref: Reddy 33/e. Pg 488

choices.text: The accused should be immediately released from custody.
The Magistrate should order an examination by a civil surgeon or designated medical officer and postpone further proceedings.
The case should be dismissed due to the mental state of the accused.
The accused should be referred directly to a psychiatrist or clinical psychologist without any initial medical examination.

questions.text: During a criminal trial, the Magistrate suspects that the accused, a 40-year-old man, is of unsound mind and incapable of making his defense. According to Sections 328 and 329 of the Criminal Procedure Code (CrPC), which of the following steps should be taken next?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) The Magistrate should order an examination by a civil surgeon or designated medical officer and postpone further proceedings.

 

Option B:

 

As per Sections 328 and 329 of the CrPC, if the Magistrate during trial finds the accused to be of unsound mind and incapable of making his defense, the correct procedure is to order the accused to be examined by the civil surgeon or any medical officer as directed by the State Government. Following this, further proceedings in the case should be postponed. This is to ensure that the accused receives a fair trial and appropriate medical evaluation.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. The accused should be immediately released from custody - Immediate release is not the prescribed procedure in such cases without proper medical evaluation and legal consideration.

 

Option C. The case should be dismissed due to the mental state of the accused - Dismissal of the case is not the immediate step; the focus is on assessing the mental state of the accused.

 

Option D. The accused should be referred directly to a psychiatrist or clinical psychologist without any initial medical examination - The first step involves examination by a civil surgeon or designated medical officer. A referral to a psychiatrist or clinical psychologist follows based on the initial assessment.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Under Sections 328 and 329 of the Criminal Procedure Code, if an accused is deemed of unsound mind during a trial, the Magistrate orders a medical examination by a civil surgeon or designated medical officer and postpones the proceedings. The civil surgeon may refer the accused to a psychiatrist for further evaluation. If dissatisfied, the accused can appeal to a Medical Board comprising a head of psychiatry from a government hospital and a psychiatry faculty member from a medical college.

 

Ref: Review of Forensic Medicine & Toxicology, Gautam Biswas, 3/e. Pg 417
